subject: Urgent: Verify Your Account Immediately
body_html:
Dear Customer,

We have detected unusual activity on your account. To prevent your account from being suspended, please verify your information immediately by clicking the link below:

https://amazon-verify-account.suspicious-site.com/verify

This is URGENT. Your account will be locked within 24 hours if you do not respond.

Best regards,
Amazon Security Team
features: Suspicious sender domain (amazon-verify.com instead of amazon.com)
Request to click a link to verify account
explanation: This is a phishing email. Legitimate companies never ask you to verify your account via email links, especially with urgent language and threats of account suspension.

subject: Your Order #12345 Has Shipped
body_html:
Hello,

Your recent order has shipped and is on its way!

Order #12345
Estimated delivery: Tomorrow by 8pm

You can track your package here: https://www.amazon.com/your-orders

Thank you for shopping with Amazon!
explanation: This is a legitimate email. It comes from the official Amazon domain, provides specific order information, and links to the official Amazon website.

subject: You've Won $10,000! Claim Your Prize Now!
body_html:
Congratulations!

You have been selected as a winner in our annual lottery! You have won $10,000!

To claim your prize, please send us the following information:
- Full name
- Date of birth
- Social Security Number
- Bank account details

Reply to this email immediately to claim your prize!

Best regards,
Lottery Prize Team
features: Request for sensitive personal information (SSN, bank details)
explanation: This is a phishing email. Legitimate lotteries don't notify winners via unsolicited emails, and they never ask for sensitive information like SSN or bank details via email.

subject: Password Reset Request
body_html:
Hi there,

We received a request to reset your password. If you made this request, click the link below:

https://github.com/password_reset?token=abc123xyz

If you didn't request this, you can safely ignore this email. Your password won't be changed.

This link will expire in 1 hour.

Thanks,
The GitHub Team
explanation: This is a legitimate password reset email. It comes from the official GitHub domain, provides clear instructions, and includes a security note about ignoring if you didn't request it.

subject: Re: Your Invoice Payment Overdue
body_html:
Dear Valued Customer,

Your invoice payment is overdue. Please pay immediately to avoid service interruption.

Amount Due: $299.99
Due Date: Yesterday

Click here to pay: http://microsoft-billing-pay.com/invoice

If you have questions, reply to this email.

Microsoft Billing Department
explanation: This is a phishing email. The sender domain (microsoft-support.net) is not Microsoft's official domain (microsoft.com), and legitimate companies don't use urgent payment threats via email.

subject: Your Netflix Subscription Renewal
body_html:
Hi,

Your Netflix subscription will renew automatically on March 15, 2025.

Plan: Standard Plan
Amount: $15.49/month

No action needed. Your payment method on file will be charged automatically.

To update your payment method or cancel, visit: https://www.netflix.com/YourAccount

Thanks for being a member!
Netflix
explanation: This is a legitimate email. It comes from Netflix's official domain structure, provides clear subscription information, and links to the official Netflix website.

subject: Suspicious Activity Detected - Action Required
body_html:
Hello,

We noticed a login attempt from an unrecognized device. For your security, we've temporarily restricted your account.

To restore access, please verify your identity by clicking here: bit.ly/paypal-verify-now

If you don't verify within 48 hours, your account will be permanently closed.

PayPal Security Team
features: Request to click link to verify
explanation: This is a phishing email. The domain is not PayPal's official domain, uses a shortened URL (red flag), and threatens account closure. Legitimate companies never ask you to verify via email links.

subject: Your Apple ID was used to sign in
body_html:
Hello,

Your Apple ID was used to sign in to iCloud on a new device.

Device: iPhone 15 Pro
Location: San Francisco, CA
Time: January 15, 2025 at 2:34 PM PST

If this was you, no action is needed.

If you don't recognize this activity, you can secure your account at: https://appleid.apple.com

Thanks,
Apple
explanation: This is a legitimate security notification. It comes from Apple's official domain, provides specific details about the sign-in, and includes a link to the official Apple ID website.

subject: Your Bank Account Has Been Compromised
body_html:
Dear Account Holder,

We have detected fraudulent activity on your account. Your account has been temporarily frozen for your protection.

To restore access, please confirm your account details:
- Account number
- Social Security Number
- Online banking password

Reply to this email with the requested information immediately.

Wells Fargo Security Department
features: Request for sensitive credentials via email
explanation: This is a phishing email. Banks never ask for sensitive information like account numbers, SSN, or passwords via email. The domain is not Wells Fargo's official domain.

subject: Your LinkedIn connection request
body_html:
Hi,

John Smith wants to connect with you on LinkedIn.

View John's profile: https://www.linkedin.com/in/johnsmith

Accept or ignore this invitation.

Best regards,
The LinkedIn Team
explanation: This is a legitimate LinkedIn notification. It comes from LinkedIn's official domain structure and provides a clear action without urgent language or suspicious links.

subject: IRS Tax Refund - Action Required
body_html:
Dear Taxpayer,

You are eligible for a tax refund of $847.50.

To receive your refund, please complete the attached form and return it within 7 days.

Click here to download: http://irs-gov-refund.com/form.pdf

Internal Revenue Service
features: Too good to be true (unsolicited refund)
explanation: This is a phishing email. The IRS never contacts taxpayers via email about refunds, and the domain is not the official irs.gov domain. Legitimate government agencies use .gov domains.

subject: Your Dropbox file has been shared
body_html:
Hi,

Sarah Johnson shared a folder with you.

Folder: Project Documents

View folder: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/abc123xyz

You can access this folder from any device.

Thanks,
The Dropbox Team
explanation: This is a legitimate Dropbox notification. It comes from Dropbox's official domain and provides clear information about a shared folder without suspicious elements.

subject: Your Package Delivery Failed
body_html:
Hello,

We attempted to deliver your package but were unable to complete the delivery.

Tracking Number: 1234567890

To reschedule delivery, please click here: bit.ly/fedex-reschedule

You must reschedule within 24 hours or your package will be returned to sender.

FedEx Delivery Team
explanation: This is a phishing email. The domain is not FedEx's official domain (fedex.com), and it uses a shortened URL. Legitimate delivery companies use their official domains and provide tracking numbers that work on their official websites.

subject: Your Zoom meeting invitation
body_html:
Hi,

You've been invited to a Zoom meeting.

Meeting: Team Standup
Organizer: Jane Doe
Time: Tomorrow at 10:00 AM EST

Join meeting: https://zoom.us/j/123456789

Meeting ID: 123 456 789

See you there!
Zoom
explanation: This is a legitimate Zoom meeting invitation. It comes from Zoom's official domain (zoom.us), provides specific meeting details, and includes a proper meeting link.

subject: Your Social Security Number is Suspended
body_html:
Dear Citizen,

Your Social Security Number has been suspended due to suspicious activity.

To reactivate your SSN, please verify your identity by providing:
- Full name
- Date of birth
- SSN
- Bank account number

Reply to this email immediately to avoid permanent suspension.

Social Security Administration
explanation: This is a phishing email. The Social Security Administration never contacts people via email about SSN issues, and SSNs cannot be 'suspended'. The domain is not the official ssa.gov domain.

subject: Your Google account security alert
body_html:
Hi there,

Someone just signed in to your Google Account from a new device.

Device: Windows PC
Location: New York, NY
Time: January 15, 2025 at 3:45 PM EST

If this was you, you can ignore this email.

If you don't recognize this activity, secure your account: https://myaccount.google.com/security

Google Account Team
explanation: This is a legitimate Google security alert. It comes from Google's official accounts domain, provides specific sign-in details, and includes a link to the official Google Account security page.

subject: Your Credit Card Statement is Ready
body_html:
Dear Customer,

Your monthly credit card statement is now available.

To view your statement, click here: http://chase-online-banking.com/statement

If you have questions about your statement, reply to this email.

Chase Bank
features: Request to click link for statement
explanation: This is a phishing email. The domain is not Chase's official domain (chase.com), and it uses HTTP instead of HTTPS. Banks always use secure HTTPS connections and their official domains.

subject: Your Spotify Premium trial is ending
body_html:
Hi,

Your Spotify Premium trial ends in 3 days.

To continue enjoying ad-free music, your payment method will be charged $9.99/month starting January 18, 2025.

No action needed. If you want to cancel, visit: https://www.spotify.com/account/subscription

Thanks for listening!
Spotify
explanation: This is a legitimate email. It comes from Spotify's official domain, provides clear information about the trial ending, and includes a link to the official Spotify account page.

subject: Your Account Will Be Deleted in 24 Hours
body_html:
Hello,

We detected a violation of our Terms of Service. Your account will be permanently deleted in 24 hours unless you verify your identity.

Click here to verify: bit.ly/fb-verify-now

This is your last chance to save your account.

Facebook Security Team
features: Request to click link to verify
explanation: This is a phishing email. The domain is not Facebook's official domain (facebook.com), uses a shortened URL, and threatens account deletion. Legitimate companies don't use such urgent threats via email.

subject: Your Uber ride receipt
body_html:
Hi,

Thanks for riding with Uber!

Trip: Downtown to Airport
Date: January 15, 2025
Fare: $24.50

View receipt: https://riders.uber.com/trips/abc123

Rate your driver: https://riders.uber.com/rate/abc123

Thanks,
Uber
explanation: This is a legitimate Uber receipt. It comes from Uber's official domain, provides specific trip details, and includes links to Uber's official rider portal.

subject: Your Amazon Prime membership expires soon
body_html:
Dear Prime Member,

Your Amazon Prime membership will expire in 5 days.

To continue enjoying Prime benefits, renew now: http://amazon-renewal.com/prime

If you don't renew, you'll lose access to Prime Video, free shipping, and more.

Amazon Prime Team
explanation: This is a phishing email. The domain is not Amazon's official domain (amazon.com), and it uses HTTP instead of HTTPS. Amazon always uses secure connections and their official domain.

subject: Your Slack workspace invitation
body_html:
Hi,

You've been invited to join the 'Engineering Team' workspace on Slack.

Join workspace: https://engineering-team.slack.com/join

If you don't want to join, you can ignore this invitation.

Welcome to Slack!
The Slack Team
explanation: This is a legitimate Slack invitation. It comes from Slack's official domain, provides clear information about the workspace invitation, and includes a proper invitation link.
